Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Threat Perception Following Mass Violence Events

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Experiencing mass violence, terrorism, or other traumatic events can shape how individuals perceive and respond to their social world. Anecdotally, following extensive media coverage of mass violence events, many report perceiving objects, people, and situations as particularly threatening; and, as media coverage shifts to emphasize resilience and community cohesion, this hypervigilance for threats seems to dissipate. Karen Quigley (Northeastern University), Yu-Ru Lin (University of Pittsburgh) and their collaborators will empirically test how emotionally potent media coverage of a real-world threat alters threat perception (i.e., the perception of a potentially harmful event, situation or stimulus as present or imminent). Specifically, they will test the hypothesis that media coverage focusing on death and destruction caused by a serious real-world threat event will have a more detrimental impact on subsequent threat perception than media coverage of the same event that focuses on people's heroic responses to the threat. This work could reveal potential harmful real-world consequences of emotionally potent media reporting of a terrorism event as well as suggest methods for alleviating such effects (e.g., by reporting on positive responses to such tragedies, like the heroics of first responders). This work will also help characterize the types of individuals who are at greatest risk of altered threat perception after a mass violence or terrorism event or when media attention to such events increases.

This project will examine the effects of real-world mass violence on threat perception among members of an affected community using multiple threat perception paradigms in the laboratory. A longitudinal study will be used to assess changes in threat perception before, during and after renewed media coverage near an upcoming anniversary of the Boston Marathon bombings, a potent real-world mass violence event that killed three and injured more than 250. The investigators will utilize novel media tracking measures to assess changes in exposure to media coverage of the bombings and threat-related events at both the community-wide and individual level. Specifically, the research will examine changes in threat perception as a result of (1) naturally-occurring changes in participants' exposure to actual media coverage of the Boston Marathon bombings near an upcoming anniversary of the tragedy and (2) in-lab exposure to media-style vignettes about the bombings that are designed to specifically activate negative or positive concepts related to the tragedy. A second, cross-sectional study will examine responses to physical threats (i.e., guns) and social threats (i.e., scowling faces) shown outside of conscious awareness. This will test whether exposure and affective framing can influence the conscious detectability of physical and social threats. Taken together, this research will provide a better understanding of how real-world mass violence and the media response to it can influence basic perceptual mechanisms that underlie changes in every day judgments and behaviors among members of the affected communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Previous research has demonstrated that exposure to incidents of mass violence, like terrorist attacks, influences how individuals feel and think about future threats to their safety. However, this previous research has largely examined the impact of exposure to terrorism on perceptions of terrorism itself, and has been limited to self-report measures. Thus, little is known about the ways in which exposure to mass violence may also shape perceptions of events in normal daily life and overt behaviors in response to potential threats. Across two studies in the present project, researchers used three different measures of threat perception to address how the impact of a mass violence incident differs for overt physical or violent threats (e.g., guns), for ambiguous social threats (e.g., threatening faces), and for threats presented subliminally (i.e., images of threatening stimuli presented such that the person is not consciously aware of having seen them). In addition, researchers measured both direct exposure to a past incident of mass violence (in this case, the Boston Marathon bombings of 2013) and indirect exposure to that same incident via media coverage. They then examined how direct and indirect exposure interacted to influence participants’ threat perceptions.  One study leveraged naturally-occurring changes in the amount of media coverage of the Boston Marathon bombings by examining participants’ threat perception at three time points surrounding the third anniversary of the bombings: once a few months before the anniversary, once in the weeks immediately preceding the anniversary when news coverage of the bombings was expected to be extensive, and once a few months after the anniversary. In addition, participants in all studies also viewed short videos related to the Boston Marathon bombings. These videos were meant to mimic media coverage of the event, and varied in terms of whether the bombings were framed more positively (i.e., focused on the bravery of first responders), were framed more negatively (i.e., focused on the death and destruction caused by the bombings), or were neutral and did not contain any content related to the bombings.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes

This research makes a significant contribution to our understanding of how acts of mass violence and terrorism influence threat perception. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first set of studies to explore the impacts of a serious community-wide threat on subsequent threat perception to non-terrorism-related threats, and thus to empirically examine how terrorism can influence basic perceptual mechanisms that underlie changes in normal, everyday judgments and behaviors after a terrorism event. Preliminary findings demonstrate that both in-lab framing of a terrorist incident and the amount of naturally occurring media coverage of the same incident outside of the lab interacted to impact threat perception bias. As such, the present studies provide critical evidence about how threat perception can change in normal, psychologically healthy individuals as a function of the kind and extent of media coverage about a mass violence incident.

Broader Impacts

The present research also motivates a number of applied impacts outside of psychological science. Understanding changes in threat perception over time could have important implications for workplace training and policies for individuals working in professions in which threat detection is an integral part of their job and where missing a possible threat has particularly high costs (e.g., law enforcement officers or military personnel). The longitudinal design of one of our studies also leaves us uniquely positioned to contribute to efforts aimed at identifying those individuals who could be more chronically affected by future terrorism threats. For example, we will be able to examine whether any of our tasks could be adapted and used as a screening procedure to provide early, accurate identification of individuals who may experience more long-term heightened arousal and disrupted threat perception as a result of such potentially impactful community-wide stressor events. This work may also have important implications for how the news media presents information about future acts of terrorism that both responsibly relays the facts without inadvertently creating detrimental community-wide effects on threat perception with potentially problematic end results.

There were also several educational impacts, including the training of two post-baccalaureate research technicians, 2 post-baccalaureate lab coordinators, and one post-doctoral researcher, all of whom have presented findings from this work at professional conferences and who are (or will be) contributing authors on manuscripts resulting from the work. It also provided opportunities for 20 part-time undergraduate research assistants who were involved in the research process. They gained experience conducting and analyzing innovative, theoretically-inspired, interdisciplinary affective science research. All of these undergraduate research assistants also authored and presented posters at professional conferences. This provided them with the opportunity to learn about data analysis and to receive training in how to properly communicate scientific findings to a professional audience. Several of these research assistants are currently pursuing graduate training in psychological science.
